game_holder_detail.title: Review, Please!!

sections.question: Given two numbers, one with more digits is the smaller number.

hint.question: Given two numbers, one with \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {more}} digits is the \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {greater}} number.
hint.solution: Given two numbers, one with \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {more}} digits is the \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {greater}} number.

sections.question: Thus, to form the greatest four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 without repeating a single digit, we need to use all four digits

hint.question: Thus, to form the  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {greatest}} four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 without repeating a single digit, we need to use  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {all four digits}}
hint.solution: Thus, to form the  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {greatest}} four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 without repeating a single digit, we need to use  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {all four digits}}

sections.question: the greatest four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 can have only 7 as the leftmost digit

hint.question: the \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {greatest}} four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 can have only  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {8 as the leftmost digit}}
hint.solution: the  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {greatest}} four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 can have only  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {8 as the leftmost digit}}

sections.question: The smallest four digit number is 1000 (one thousand)

hint.question: The smallest four digit number is  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {1000}} (one thousand)
hint.solution: The smallest four digit number is  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {1000}} (one thousand)

sections.question: In the Indian system of numeration we have commas after 3 digits starting from the right and thereafter every 2 digits

hint.question: In the Indian system of numeration we have commas after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {3 digits starting from the right}} and thereafter  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {every 2 digits}}
hint.solution: In the Indian system of numeration we have commas after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {3 digits starting from the right}} and thereafter  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {every 2 digits}}

sections.question: The commas after 3, 6 and 7 digits separate thousand, lakh and crore respectively.

hint.question: The commas after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {3, 5 and 7 digits}} separate thousand, lakh and crore respectively.
hint.solution: The commas after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {3, 5 and 7 digits}} separate thousand, lakh and crore respectively.

sections.question: In the International system of numeration commas are placed after every 3 digits starting from the right

hint.question: In the International system of numeration commas are placed after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {every 3 digits}} starting from the right
hint.solution: In the International system of numeration commas are placed after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {every 3 digits}} starting from the right

sections.question: The commas after 6 and 9 digits separate thousand and million respectively

hint.question: The commas after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {3 and 6 digits}} separate thousand and million respectively
hint.solution: The commas after  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {3 and 6 digits}} separate thousand and million respectively

sections.question: Estimation involves approximating a quantity to an accuracy required. Thus, 4117 may be approximated to 4200 or to 4000, i.e. to the nearest hundred or to the nearest thousand depending on our need

hint.question: Estimation involves approximating a quantity to an accuracy required. Thus, 4117 may be approximated to  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {4100}} or to  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {4000}}, i.e. to the nearest hundred or to the nearest thousand depending on our need
hint.solution: Estimation involves approximating a quantity to an accuracy required. Thus, 4117 may be approximated to  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {4100}} or to  \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {4000}}, i.e. to the nearest hundred or to the nearest thousand depending on our need

sections.question: kilo shows 1000 times larger, thus, 1 kilometre = 1000 metres

hint.question: kilo shows \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {1000}} times larger, thus, 1 kilometre = 1000 metres
hint.solution: kilo shows \bg[07c]{\color[cyan] {1000}} times larger, thus, 1 kilometre = 1000 metres

content_report.title: Given two numbers, one with more digits is the smaller number.
Thus, to form the greatest four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 without repeating a single digit, we need to use all four digits
the greatest four digit number from 7, 8, 3, 5 can have only 7 as the leftmost digit
The smallest four digit number is 1000 (one thousand)
In the Indian system of numeration we have commas after 3 digits starting from the right and thereafter every 2 digits
The commas after 3, 6 and 7 digits separate thousand, lakh and crore respectively.
In the International system of numeration commas are placed after every 3 digits starting from the right
The commas after 6 and 9 digits separate thousand and million respectively
Estimation involves approximating a quantity to an accuracy required. Thus, 4117 may be approximated to 4200 or to 4000, i.e. to the nearest hundred or to the nearest thousand depending on our need
kilo shows 1000 times larger, thus, 1 kilometre = 1000 metres
